questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.

questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is usually 6-7 cm. This measurement is essential in gynecological evaluations and procedures.
  • This measurement helps in assessing normal uterine anatomy and can be used in various clinical procedures such as the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Ovary: The ovary measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm.
  • Fallopian Tube: The length of the Fallopian tube is about 10 cm, and the lumen is 1-2 mm at the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is 6-7 cm.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition Pg 25, Dutta's textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 7

questions.text:
Among the given statements, which one would lead you to consider primary amenorrhea as a possibility? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age
  2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche
  3. High levels of TSH and short stature
  4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation in a girl who has not attained menarche by a certain age or who lacks secondary sexual characteristics. Specifically:

 

1. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age: This is a classic indicator of primary amenorrhea, particularly if secondary sexual characteristics have developed. It is an age by which menstruation should have started if there are signs of puberty.

 

2. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche: Thelarche, or breast development, typically occurs around ages 9 to 13. If menarche has not occurred within 3 years after thelarche, it is a reason to investigate primary amenorrhea.

 

4. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age: The absence of breast development by age 13 indicates a delay in puberty and warrants evaluation for primary amenorrhea if menstruation has not begun by this age.

 

Other Option:

 

3. High levels of TSH and short stature: While high TSH and short stature may indicate thyroid dysfunction or other endocrine issues, they are not direct indicators of primary amenorrhea. These findings might contribute to secondary causes of amenorrhea or other growth disorders but are not themselves diagnostic criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea should be considered if there is failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age, failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche, or failure of breast development by 13 years of age.

choices.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body
Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct
Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

 

Explanation:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body: This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.

 

Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct: This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.

 

Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia: This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

choices.text: Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
It is dependent on psychological factors
Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of these statements regarding primary dysmenorrhea is true? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It Is dependent on psychological factors

 

Primary dysmenorrhea can be dependent on psychological factors.

 

Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours and Option C. Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period: Pain begins before or with onset of menstrual periods.

 

Option D. GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment: NSAIDs are the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by menstrual pain without underlying pelvic pathology, can be influenced by psychological factors. This type of dysmenorrhea begins before or with the onset of menstrual periods and is typically treated first with NSAIDs, not GnRH antagonists.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Causes of secondary amenorrhea:

 

  • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.

 

Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.

 

Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg375

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism in men is seen with deficiency of? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace mineral that plays a crucial role in various biological functions, including immune response, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. It is also vital for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, as well as for proper reproductive function.

 

Zinc Deficiency and Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in men can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism. Hypogonadism refers to reduced function of the gonads (testes in men), which can lead to lower testosterone levels and may result in symptoms such as decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and reduced secondary sexual characteristics. Zinc is important for the synthesis of testosterone and its deficiency can impair reproductive health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is essential for male reproductive health, and its deficiency can lead to delayed sexual maturation and hypogonadism.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

 

Anterior colporrhaphy is performed for cystocele.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

choices.text: Epithelial cells covered by bacteria
Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods
Doderlein bacili in the macrophage

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes in with a grayish-white vaginal discharge. Upon conducting a gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are observed. What are clue cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells that are covered by bacteria, which gives them a distinctive appearance. In the context of bacterial vaginosis, these cells appear with a fuzzy or irregular border due to the presence of small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis, a condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degranulated neutrophils: Degranulated neutrophils are not clue cells. Neutrophils are involved in the immune response, and their degranulation refers to the release of granules that contain enzymes and other substances. They do not have the fuzzy appearance characteristic of clue cells.

 

Option C. Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods: Gardenella vaginalis is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis, but clue cells are not specifically Gardenella vaginalis with Bacillin rods. Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by various types of bacteria, not a specific bacterium or rod-shaped bacteria.

 

Option D. Doderlein bacilli in the macrophage: Doderlein bacilli (lactobacilli) are normally present in the vagina and help maintain a healthy environment. They are not found within macrophages, nor are they related to the appearance of clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by bacteria, and their presence is indicative of bacterial vaginosis.

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings:  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. 
  • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

 

Educational Objective:

 

To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:

 

  • Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency.
  • Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring.
  • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins.
  • Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg 380,

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose unicornuate uterus?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Falloposcopy
  2. Laparoscopy
  3. HSG
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

2. Laparoscopy: This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, including the uterus. It is effective in diagnosing structural anomalies like a unicornuate uterus.

 

3. HSG (Hysterosalpingogram): This is an X-ray procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It helps in visualizing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, making it useful in diagnosing a unicornuate uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 4: While laparoscopy (2) is correct, X-ray (4) alone is not specific or detailed enough to diagnose a unicornuate uterus.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Falloposcopy (1) is used to visualize the interior of the fallopian tubes, not to diagnose uterine anomalies. Laparoscopy (2) is correct but falloposcopy is not appropriate for this diagnosis.

 

Option C. 1, 3: Similar to option B, falloposcopy (1) is not relevant for diagnosing uterine anomalies, even though HSG (3) is correct.

 

  • Falloposcopy: Refers to the visualization of the interior of the fallopian tube lumen and tubal ostia using a flexible fiber optic device via hysteroscope.
  • Diagnosis of Mullerian Anomalies: Can be achieved through various methods, including:
    1. Ultrasound (Preferably 3D USG)
    2. MRI (Investigation of choice)
    3. HSG
    4. Hystero-laparoscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy and HSG are effective diagnostic tools for identifying unicornuate uterus and other Mullerian anomalies.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 47, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg418

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

choices.text: Amniotic fluid volume
Daily fetal movement count

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:

 

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.

 

  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal tone
    5. Fetal breathing movements
  • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 122

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.

 

Option C. Syphilis: A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition page no 926

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

choices.text: Weight loss+ Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation
Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation
Weight loss+ Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, experiencing 6 years of infertility, possesses a BMI of 33 and exhibits facial hair. Further investigations have diagnosed her with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and observed tubal spillage from both sides. Given her desire to conceive with her husband, what would be the most suitable management plan for her? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

 

Notably, even a modest weight loss (approximately 5% of body weight) can be beneficial for restoring ovulatory cycles in some obese PCOS patients. Therefore, spontaneous induction is attempted as the first option. Additionally, folic acid is routinely administered as a preventive measure before conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins: While weight loss and Metformin are both appropriate treatments for PCOS, initiating ovulation induction with urinary gonadotrophins might be premature. Typically, less invasive methods such as Clomiphene or Letrozole are tried before using gonadotrophins.

 

Option C. Metformin + finasteride + Induction of ovulation: This option includes Metformin, which is beneficial for insulin resistance in PCOS, and finasteride, which is used for hirsutism but not typically for fertility management. Finasteride is not used to induce ovulation. This plan overlooks the initial approach of weight loss and the potential for spontaneous ovulation.

 

Option D. Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene: This option is partially correct. While weight loss and Metformin are appropriate, the recommendation to immediately use Clomiphene for induction without trying for spontaneous ovulation is not aligned with the step-wise approach in fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with PCOS and infertility, the initial management should include weight loss and folic acid supplementation, with attempts at spontaneous ovulation before progressing to more invasive induction methods.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

questions.text: What should be the ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4%

 

Explanation:

 

  • Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
  • As per the strict criteria, >4% normal forms of morphology must be present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis is >4% according to WHO 2010 criteria.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg442, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.

 

Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. late decelerations are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.

 

Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Velamentous insertion of the cord
﻿﻿﻿Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

questions.text: The given image depicts: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Succenturiate lobe: This refers to a placenta with one or more accessory lobes connected to the main part of the placenta by blood vessels. It is characterized by the presence of a smaller, separate lobe in addition to the main placental mass.
  • Velamentous insertion of the cord: This occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (chorioamnion) rather than directly into the placental mass. The vessels then travel through the membranes to reach the placenta, making them vulnerable to rupture.
  • The image shows both conditions: a smaller accessory lobe (succenturiate lobe) and the cord inserting into the membranes rather than the placenta (velamentous insertion).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Succenturiate lobe: This option is partially correct but does not account for the velamentous insertion.

 

Option B. Velamentous insertion of the cord: This option is partially correct but does not account for the succenturiate lobe.

 

Option D. Normal placenta: This is incorrect as the image shows abnormalities not seen in a normal placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A placenta with both a succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord is characterized by the presence of a smaller accessory lobe and the umbilical cord inserting into the fetal membranes.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg122, 117, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 251,253

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the OPD. She has Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characters. Her karyotype is 46XX. FSH is 5 and LH is 13. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

 

The patient presents with primary amenorrhea, Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characteristics, a 46XX karyotype, and normal gonadotropin levels (FSH and LH). The development of secondary sexual characteristics indicates that the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is functioning properly, which usually suggests normal ovarian function. Mullerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a condition where the uterus and part of the vaginal canal are absent, but ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics remain normal. This condition commonly presents with primary amenorrhea in individuals with a 46XX karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis refers to underdeveloped or non-functional gonads, leading to low estrogen levels and subsequent lack of secondary sexual characteristics. In this case, FSH and LH levels would typically be elevated, not normal.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a lack of secondary sexual development due to low levels of gonadotropins (FSH and LH). This condition usually presents with delayed or absent puberty, unlike the normal Tanner stage IV development seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS): AIS involves individuals with a 46XY karyotype who are phenotypically female due to the body's inability to respond to androgens. This patient has a 46XX karyotype, ruling out AIS as a possible diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis is a likely diagnosis in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual development, normal FSH/LH levels, and a 46XX karyotype.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

choices.text: Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile
Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:


The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.

 

Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.

 

Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.

 

Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.

 

Educational Objective:


The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.

 

Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months
Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months of starting primary therapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months  of starting primary therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Platinum-refractory disease: This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all.
  • Platinum-resistant disease: This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis.
  • Platinum-sensitive disease: This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months: This statement is incorrect. If the recurrence occurs more than 12 months after treatment, it is considered platinum-sensitive, not resistant.

 

Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months: This statement is not a recognized classification. The classification focuses on the 6-month mark to distinguish between resistant and sensitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platinum-sensitive recurrent ovarian cancer is characterized by a recurrence occurring more than 6 months after completing primary therapy.

 

 

Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1387

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence for the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing is as follows:

 

Procedure of taking a pap smear:

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco's speculum is introduced to visualize the cervix.
  2. Take the sample: The ectocervix is scraped with Ayre's spatula, and the endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  3. Make smear on a slide: The samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  4. Fix the smear: The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol (either immersed or sprayed). After immersion in fixative for 30 minutes, the slide is removed and air dried.

 

Additional Steps:

 

  • Staining: The fixed slide is stained with Papanicolaou stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for collecting samples for a pap smear is to first use a posterior vaginal wall retractor to visualize the cervix, take the sample, make the smear on a slide, and then fix the smear using 95% ethyl alcohol.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 55-85 years

 

55-85 years: Correct. The majority of vulval cancer cases are diagnosed in women aged 55 to 85 years. The average age of diagnosis is between 60 and 65 years.

 

Vulval cancer primarily affects older women, and its age distribution is as follows:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not age specific: Incorrect. Vulval cancer is not "not age specific"; it is specifically associated with an older age group.

 

Option B. 35-55 years: Incorrect. Although vulval cancer can occur in younger women, the majority of cases are diagnosed in the older age group, typically between 55 and 85 years.

 

Option D. Both of the above: Incorrect. The age distribution for vulval cancer does not cover both age groups mentioned (35-55 years and 55-85 years) equally. The more accurate distribution is predominantly in the 55-85 years range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval cancer predominantly affects women aged 55 to 85 years, with the average diagnosis occurring between 60 and 65 years.

 

Ref: Page no 333, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A woman who is using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) experiences white vaginal discharge without itching or a foul odor. The discharge causes yellow staining on her underwear. Upon examination, the discharge reveals the presence of typical lactobacilli and an acidic pH. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased normal vaginal discharge

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Leucorrhea (Increased vaginal discharge). Leucorrhea presents with excessive whitish, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge. It is non-irritant, no purulent and non-offensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents with itching and a white thick, curdy discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option D. Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia infection can by asymptomatic or present with discharge but is not associated with yellow discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased normal vaginal discharge, known as leucorrhea, can occur in women using oral contraceptive pills. This discharge is typically white or yellow, non-irritant, no purulent, no offensive, and associated with the presence of lactobacilli and an acidic pH.

choices.text: Luteal phase LH
Post luteal phase LH
FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • Values and Interpretation:
    • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
    • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL

 

Tests for ovarian reserve:

 

  • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg435

choices.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.
Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given
Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of acute onset fever, and pain in the right lumbar region. It is associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

 

Explanation:

 

The management of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy involves several key steps to ensure effective treatment and prevent complications:

 

  • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.
  • Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy.
  • Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (≥50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration.
  • Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. The correct management protocol dictates:

 

  • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours, not 72 hours.
  • Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days, not just 5 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics: Correct. Hospitalization, urine and blood cultures, and starting antibiotics are all appropriate steps in managing acute pyelonephritis.

 

Option B. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Correct. Switching to oral antibiotics is appropriate once the patient is afebrile.

 

Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given: Correct. Maintaining a urine output of > 50 mL/h and using intravenous crystalloids are standard practices to manage hydration and ensure adequate renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discharge from the hospital should be considered once the patient is afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics should be continued for 7 to 10 days in cases of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

choices.text: 5 alpha reductase deficiency
17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
Androgen insensitivity syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple screening test includes Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP), and Inhibin A. Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple test.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition
