questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can promote the growth of endometriotic lesions. Estradiol is a form of estrogen, which can stimulate the endometrial tissue and potentially exacerbate the symptoms and progression of endometriosis. The goal in managing endometriosis is to reduce estrogen levels or block estrogen’s effects to help resolve the lesions and alleviate symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is used in the treatment of endometriosis. Medroxyprogesterone acetate is a type of progesterone that helps create a state of endometrial atrophy, which can reduce the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Option B. Cabergoline: This drug is typically used to treat hyperprolactinemia but is not a standard treatment for endometriosis. While not commonly used in endometriosis management, its use is not contraindicated as estradiol is.

 

Option D. Letrozole: This is an aromatase inhibitor that lowers estrogen levels and is used in the treatment of endometriosis. By reducing estrogen levels, letrozole helps decrease the growth of endometriotic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is avoided in the treatment of endometriosis because it can exacerbate the condition by promoting the growth of endometriotic lesions

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

choices.text: High fetal head station

questions.text: All are causes of uterine dysfunction, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

Explanation:

 

  • Multiparity is not a cause of uterine dysfunction; rather, nulliparity (the condition of a woman who has never given birth) is a recognized cause. Uterine dysfunction, particularly hypotonic uterine dysfunction, is associated with several factors, but multiparity is generally associated with a more efficient labor process due to the body's previous experience with childbirth.

 

Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction:

 

  • Neuraxial analgesia: The use of epidural or spinal anesthesia can interfere with uterine contractions.
  • Chorioamnionitis: This is an infection of the amniotic fluid and membranes, which can lead to inflammation and impaired uterine contractility.
  • Nulliparity: First-time mothers (nulliparous women) are more likely to experience uterine dysfunction due to the unconditioned nature of the uterine muscles.
  • Other factors:
    • Mechanical disruption of myometrial function by a fibroid or pelvic tumor
    • Maternal obesity
    • Uterine mullerian anomaly
    • Increased maternal age
    • Malposition and malpresentation of the fetus
    • Contracted pelvis

 

Other options:

 

Option A. High fetal head station: High fetal head station can be associated with labor dystocia and uterine dysfunction as it may indicate issues with the descent of the baby.

 

Option C. Multiparity: Neuraxial block (e.g., epidural) can interfere with effective uterine contractions, leading to uterine dysfunction.

 

Option D. Chorioamnionitis: Chorioamnionitis, an infection, can impair uterine contractions and lead to dysfunctional labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity, not multiparity, is a cause of uterine dysfunction. Causes of hypotonic uterine dysfunction include neuraxial analgesia, chorioamnionitis, nulliparity, and mechanical factors such as fibroids or pelvic tumors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg459, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 416

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LH: Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

 

Option C. FSH: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 66

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

This patient is presenting with chronic hypertension that has progressed to superimposed preeclampsia, indicated by the development of 3+ proteinuria, a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg, and symptoms such as headache and blurring of vision. These symptoms and her elevated blood pressure suggest severe preeclampsia.

 

  • Severe Preeclampsia: A systolic blood pressure greater than 160 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 110 mmHg, along with symptoms like headache and visual disturbances, are indicators of severe preeclampsia. In this case, the patient’s condition requires urgent management to prevent the development of eclampsia, a condition that can lead to seizures and other severe complications.
  • Management: The correct management for severe preeclampsia at 36 weeks gestation includes the administration of Labetalol to lower the blood pressure, Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to prevent seizures, and expedited delivery to resolve the preeclampsia. After 34 weeks of gestation, delivery is recommended for severe preeclampsia because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO4 + Wait till 37 weeks: As this is severe preeclampsia, there is a very high risk waiting till 37 weeks. Immediate delivery is indicated after 34 weeks

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + wait till 37 weeks: There is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks and also there is no indication to wait till 37 weeks as this is severe preeclampsia

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Although delivery needs to be expedited, there is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Measure CA 125 levels
Follow up after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and size less than 8 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6-12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Functional Ovarian Cyst: In reproductive-aged women, a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm is likely functional.
  • Follow-Up: The recommended management is to follow up after 6-12 weeks with a repeat ultrasound to check if the cyst resolves on its own.
  • Indications for Further Intervention: Surgical treatment is warranted if there are worrying features, the cyst is greater than 8 cm, there are significant symptoms, or CA-125 levels are raised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA 125 levels: CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and is more relevant in postmenopausal women. It has limited role in premenopausal women with clear, simple cysts.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: Surgical intervention such as laparoscopy is not immediately necessary for a 5 cm cyst unless there are concerning features or persistence after follow-up.

 

Option D. CT pelvis: CT scan is not typically indicated for initial assessment of a simple ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound.

 

Additional information:

 

  • OC Pills: Oral contraceptive pills have not been proven effective in treating simple ovarian cysts, though they are often used.
  • Simple Ovarian Cysts: Any simple ovarian cyst less than 5 cm without symptoms can be left alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.

 

Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg217

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anovulation

 

Explanation:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate:
    • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Mifepristone + misoprostol: A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Manual vacuum aspiration: This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
    • Dilatation and curettage: Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Dilatation and evacuation is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg203

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat PCOD? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is not commonly used in the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Medical Management of PCOD:
    • OCP (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones and are given to women who are not desirous of fertility to regularize their cycles.
    • Metformin (Option B): Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, which decreases hyperinsulinemia and improves fertility in patients with PCOD.
    • Ovulation Induction Drugs:
      • Clomiphene (Option A): Clomiphene citrate is commonly used to induce ovulation in women with infertility due to PCOD.
      • Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in PCOD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene is an ovulation induction agent used in the treatment of infertility in women with PCOD.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is used to decrease insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia in PCOD, which can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving fertility.

 

Option D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills are used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage hormonal imbalances in women with PCOD who do not seek to become pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is not typically used in the treatment of PCOD. Instead, treatments include oral contraceptive pills, metformin, and ovulation induction agents such as clomiphene and letrozole.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition. Pg 398 Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg470

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol

 

Estrogens play a crucial role in the development and regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the natural estrogens, estradiol is the most potent. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the predominant estrogen during the reproductive years of a woman. It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors, making it the most effective at eliciting estrogenic responses in the body.

 

Estrone, on the other hand, is the main estrogen found in postmenopausal women and is less potent than estradiol. Estriol is the weakest of the three natural estrogens and is predominantly produced during pregnancy. Conjugated equine estrogen is a mixture of estrogens derived from the urine of pregnant mares and is less potent than estradiol.

 

Therefore, estradiol is considered the most potent natural estrogen due to its strong affinity for estrogen receptors and its significant role in reproductive physiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrone: Although it is a natural estrogen, estrone is less potent than estradiol. It is primarily found in postmenopausal women and does not exert the same level of estrogenic activity as estradiol.

 

Option C. Estriol: This estrogen is the least potent of the natural estrogens and is mainly produced during pregnancy. It has a much lower affinity for estrogen receptors compared to estradiol.

 

Option D. Conjugated equine estrogen: This is a semi-synthetic mixture of estrogens obtained from horses. While it is used in hormone replacement therapy, its potency is lower than that of estradiol and it is not considered a single natural estrogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: Following delivery of a preterm baby, the baby died in the NICU despite all efforts. What medication would be given to the mother for reducing breast tenderness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cabergoline

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist and is the drug of choice for suppressing lactation. It works by inhibiting prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland, which reduces milk production and alleviates breast engorgement and tenderness.

 

Cabergoline is preferred because it is effective, has a favorable side effect profile, and is well-tolerated by most patients. It is also used in conditions like galactorrhea where suppression of lactation is desired.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: While dopamine agonists like cabergoline work to suppress prolactin, dopamine itself is not used directly for this purpose in clinical settings. Cabergoline, being a dopamine agonist, is more specifically tailored for this function.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Ergot alkaloids have some dopamine agonist activity and can suppress prolactin, but they are not the drug of choice for lactation suppression due to their side effects and less favorable risk profile compared to cabergoline.

 

Option D. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog used to prevent gastric ulcers, induce labor, and manage postpartum hemorrhage, but it has no role in lactation suppression or reducing breast tenderness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline is the preferred medication for suppressing lactation and reducing breast tenderness in cases where breastfeeding is not desired or possible, such as after neonatal death

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

 

The correct answer is MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic). The classification of twin pregnancies is based on the timing of the zygote's division and the resulting structures, such as the number of chorions (placentas) and amnions (amniotic sacs) that form.

 

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins occur when the division happens very early (within the first 72 hours after fertilization), resulting in two separate chorions and amnions.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA) twins occur when the division happens between the 4th and 8th day after fertilization, after the chorion has formed but before the amniotic sac has split.
  • Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins result from division that occurs between the 9th and 12th day after fertilization, after both the chorion and amnion have formed, leading to two embryos sharing a single amniotic sac and a single chorion.
  • Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible scenario. The formation of a single amnion with two separate chorions (placentas) does not occur because the chorion forms before the amnion. Thus, this combination is anatomically and developmentally impossible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. MCMA (Monochorionic Monoamniotic): This is a recognized type of twin pregnancy where twins share both the chorion and the amnion.

 

Option B. MCDA (Monochorionic Diamniotic): Another recognized type, where twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. DADC (Dichorionic Diamniotic): This is the most common type of twin pregnancy, especially in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, where each twin has its own chorion and amnion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: ABO incompatibility
Parvovirus B19
Alpha thalassemia major

questions.text: All of the subsequent factors can lead to non-immune hydrops except for: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

Explanation:

 

Non-immune hydrops refers to fetal hydrops that occur due to causes other than those related to maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility. ABO incompatibility is an immune-related cause of hydrops, known as immune hydrops, where the mother's immune system attacks the fetus's red blood cells due to incompatible ABO blood types. Non-immune hydrops arises from various other causes such as cardiovascular issues, genetic disorders, congenital infections, hematologic disorders, placental problems, and miscellaneous conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Parvovirus B19: This is a viral infection that can cause non-immune hydrops by affecting the fetus's red blood cells, leading to severe anemia and hydrops.

 

Option C. Chromosomal defect: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as trisomy 21, 18, or 13, can cause non-immune hydrops through associated congenital abnormalities or malformations.

 

Option D. Alpha thalassemia major: This is a hematologic disorder that results in severe anemia, which can lead to non-immune hydrops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABO incompatibility leads to immune hydrops and is not a cause of non-immune hydrops.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage in sequence? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Serial dilation
  2. Curettage
  3. Uterine sound
  4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-3-1-2

 

The correct sequence for performing a dilation and curettage (D&C) is as follows:

 

4. Assessment of uterine size and direction : Before any procedure, the first step is to assess the size and direction of the uterus to plan the approach and ensure that any interventions are appropriately targeted.

 

3. Uterine sound : The next step involves using a uterine sound to measure the depth and assess the shape and orientation of the uterine cavity. This helps to guide the subsequent dilation process.

 

1. Serial dilation : After assessing the uterus, serial dilation of the cervix is performed using progressively larger dilators to allow access to the uterine cavity.

 

2. Curettage : Finally, curettage is performed to remove the contents of the uterine cavity, which completes the D&C procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for dilation and curettage (D&C) is to first assess the uterus, perform uterine sounding, then serial dilation, and finally proceed with curettage.

 

Ref: Page no 585, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions:
    • In girls:
      • T-shaped uterus
      • Cockscomb cervix
      • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
    • In boys:
      • Micropenis
      • Hypospadias
      • Undescended testes

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Sarcoma botryoides: Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg42
